title: 107_hr90
content:
The "Know Your Caller Act of 2001" prohibits interference with caller identification services. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a new subsection prohibiting interference with caller identification services during telephone solicitations within the United States. The Know Your Caller Act of 2001 prohibits interference with caller identification services during telephone solicitations in the United States. The FCC must establish regulations within 6 months to enforce this prohibition. The Know Your Caller Act of 2001 prohibits interference with caller identification services during telephone solicitations in the United States. The prohibition includes disclosing the caller's name, the entity on whose behalf the call is made, and a valid contact number for opting out of future calls. The regulations (47 CFR 64.1200) require the maintenance of a do-not-call list by individuals or entities. The list can only be used for enforcement purposes and not for marketing or transfer/sale. A private right of action allows individuals to bring legal action in state courts for violations, seeking injunctions or monetary damages up to $500. The regulations require maintaining a do-not-call list for enforcement purposes only. Individuals can take legal action in state courts for violations, seeking injunctions or damages up to $500 per violation. If the violation is willful or knowing, the court may increase the award up to 3 times the amount. Definitions include caller identification service and telephone call. The term 'telephone call' encompasses any transmission to or from a telephone number, including calls made over the Internet. It also includes calls made by automated systems, digital networks, and mobile radio sources. SEC. 3. Effect on State Law and State Actions: Amends the Communications Act of 1934 regarding the prohibition of certain telephone solicitations. 

SEC. 4. Study Regarding Transmission of Caller Identification Information. The FCC will conduct a study to determine the capability of the public switched network and telecommunications equipment in the telemarketing industry to transmit caller identification information on all telephone calls, including necessary changes and associated costs. The FCC will conduct a study on the capability of the public switched network and telecommunications equipment in the telemarketing industry to transmit caller identification information on all calls, including associated costs. The Commission will submit a report to Congress within one year of the enactment of this Act. Passed the House of Representatives on December 4, 2001.
